I think we need the full host host list:
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/stable-2.9/lib/ansible/modules/cloud/openstack/os_nova_host_aggregate.py#L157

and that finally brings us to the conclusion that the issue is 
always in the nova_compute group contents, nor the nova_host facts, neither the os_nova_host_aggregate module.

Though blacklisting a node normally could be because the node is not available for some reason (can be removed from aggregates), it may be possible they are blacklisted just not to run deployments.

We can't get it from ansible if the blacklisted nodes have to stay in aggregates. Caching the fact won't help either as we clear the cache for every run[1].

Yeah possibly. I thought there would also be a case to remove blacklisted nodes (nova compute is dead or hardware issue to be fixed) from aggregates?

since the hosts part of the equation seems always getting expected values extracted from hiera, I assume the problem is here https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/stable-2.9/lib/ansible/modules/cloud/openstack/os_nova_host_aggregate.py#L123

which results in unexpected aggregate.hosts result. And then

for i in (set(hosts) - set(aggregate.hosts))

eventually returns that badly formatted entry

and here I failed again... The set aggregate.hosts must be a subset of hosts to return non-empty result. That means the problem comes from the set(hosts) part of the equation, so it should be on our side...
nm, it comes from nova::host in hiera and can never take a list value

Not sure I understand all of your comments here. As I've commented earlier with example, when nova_host is not defined for a compute below is passed as 'hosts' to ansible module. 

Without patch:

"['compute-0.redhat.local', Undefined]"

So it's treated as a string by the module and then it splits it.

With patch:

["compute-0.redhat.local"]

I think this patch would fix the issue. But the concern by owalsh of having nova_hosts for blacklisted nodes as well is not addressed by this patch. However we can still merge this patch to send proper list to the ansible module.

neutron/api/rpc/handlers/securitygroups_.message: what should be the caller of this method?

The callback _handle_address_group_event in line 309 below is called when updates to address groups arrived from the RPC wire and got reflected in the resource cache. That callback in turn calls either of the two methods that I added to the security groups agent here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/759117/2/neutron/agent/securitygroups_rpc.py@215

These methods initiate the processing in the security group agent of the updates to address groups. Those methods only received the address group id. At some point, those methods or methods called by them need to retrieve the entire address group

kuryr_kubernetes/controller/drivers/util.message:
probably this functions requires some docstring.

What does it mean labels = None? Since in NPs (for the selectors) is is not the same None, than [], or than {} (https://github.com/openstack/kuryr-kubernetes/blob/master/doc/source/devref/network_policy.rst#network-policy-rule-definition)

`podSelector` is different than pod `labels`. Pod's metadata does not require `labels` to exist and we often fetch them using `pod['metadata'].get('labels'). So if pod has no labels at all we'll get None. The idea is that None effectively means empty dictionary {} of labels.
the default valus for labels does not affect crd_expressions?
It shouldn't, lines 395-398 will still get executed if pod has no labels at all.

nova/service.py.message:
Thinking about this fresh this week, I'm a teensy bit worried that this might be a tad aggressive for anyone doing a rolling upgrade where they have some ancient compute that is still checking in but is effectively not able to participate. Like, some compute node that has been nearly walled off with some yet-to-exit workload running on it. With this abort (which I agree with on principle) they'll have to stop it or seal it off and then wait a minute for the aging of the timer before they can start anything new.

That said, I think that's what we're going for here, so let's forge ahead and "fix it in post" if someone complains.

I have a similar concern. I'm thinking about scenarios where someone is running multiple cells and has disabled one or more cells with too old computes in it, or has disabled compute nodes that are too old ... And imagining them unable to run the cluster at all in this state from now on.

I think at the least it might be good to have a reno for this because of the change in behavior?

I'm also curious, was there a bug report or specific incident that inspired this change (re: no Related-Bug in the commit message)? I ask because I think this change might be noticeable, particularly for multi-cell users and I wasn't sure what brought it about.

Previously, we have had a ServiceTooOld exception that is raised in particular cases where a service is too old, but we did not (for some reason) seek to block the deployment from running because of it.

To be clear, I'm not expressing opposition to this change, just trying to think about it more.

> Thanks for the feedback. I appreciate it. Let's see the scenarios:
 > 
 > * There is an old compute (< N-1) that cannot fully participate in
 > RPC any more but the basic things might still work. E.g. status
 > reporting, server create/delete. If this is what is only needed for
 > that deployment then by the current patch we basically break that
 > working deployment.
 > 
 > * There is an old and disabled compute in the system. As it is
 > disable we don't expect that it is used from the controller. If
 > this is a valid use case to keep old computes disable in the
 > system, then we break that use case by this patch. Alternatively we
 > could come up with a rule that only count enabled computes in
 > startup service level check.
 > 
 > It feels like this is a policy question.
 > 
 > Does nova have a hard policy to only support N -> N + 1 upgrade?

It has to have that policy right now, and I agree that this enforces that and should.

 > If yes, then this patch simply enforces such policy, and by that
 > allows us to freely delete a bunch of compatibility code earlier.
 > 
 > If no, then we might need to agree what could be an enforceable
 > policy. Delete compatibility code at N + 2 only? Then I would
 > propose this same change with an abort at N - 2 compute service
 > level. So that I can remove the compatibility code an N + 2 safely.
 > 
 > Or alternatively we can keep saying that the policy is that nova
 > only supports N -> N + 1 upgrades, but we do not enforce it but
 > instead we enforce a less strict N - 2 service level check.

I would much rather be strict about it. We only test N-1, we only expect that to work, and we already do things in places where we way "I added that last cycle so I'm good to depend on it". The service version checks are mostly used for in-version upgrades so we know when we can enable something that we added in a single release, but need to wait for everything to be upgraded.

I'm for strict enforcement, definitely. I just wanted to note that it was a strict check, and it might catch someone off guard when they realize (likely unintentionally) that some un-upgraded compute is still on the network somewhere causing them problems.

Anyway, please continue with this, I was just making a point earlier. The only reason I didn't +2 was the question in the other file, which I haven't seen an answer to.

Thanks for the feedback. I appreciate it. Let's see the scenarios:

* There is an old compute (< N-1) that cannot fully participate in RPC any more but the basic things might still work. E.g. status reporting, server create/delete. If this is what is only needed for that deployment then by the current patch we basically break that working deployment.

* There is an old and disabled compute in the system. As it is disable we don't expect that it is used from the controller. If this is a valid use case to keep old computes disable in the system, then we break that use case by this patch. Alternatively we could come up with a rule that only count enabled computes in startup service level check.

It feels like this is a policy question. 

Does nova have a hard policy to only support N -> N + 1 upgrade? 

If yes, then this patch simply enforces such policy, and by that allows us to freely delete a bunch of compatibility code earlier. 

If no, then we might need to agree what could be an enforceable policy. Delete compatibility code at N + 2 only? Then I would propose this same change with an abort at N - 2 compute service level. So that I can remove the compatibility code an N + 2 safely.

Or alternatively we can keep saying that the policy is that nova only supports N -> N + 1 upgrades, but we do not enforce it but instead we enforce a less strict N - 2 service level check.

Just a note, I'm the one that suggested that we take this enforcement up a notch. I think I recommended a warning, although I think warnings do go unnoticed at times. I think if we're going to remove stuff that depends on service version one cycle after we release it, that we need to reeeealy stick to our guns about N-to-N+1-only upgrades and enforcement in code helps with that.

So, I'm not opposed to the failure, and I think we *should* abort like this, I just wanted to note that it came to mind.

neutron_lib/api/converters.py.message:
This will add extra lines to the error log like 
The above exception was the direct cause of...... am I right?

Yes, it will add more context to the message, this was a good explanation I found:

"The difference is that when you use from, the __cause__ attribute is set and the message states that the exception was directly caused by. If you omit the from then no __cause__ is set, but the __context__ attribute may be set as well, and the traceback then shows the context as during handling something else happened."

swift/common/memcached.py.message: nit: I guess now could be used in place of time.time() on this line

By adding the '=' aren't we changing the contract people might have come to expect? Ie. we used to error limit, according to this code one the 11th time in the last minute (because > ERROR_LIMIT_COUNT) and now we'll error limit on the 10th (>= ERROR_LMIT_COUNT).

I'm not against the change, but it might mean it's something that should be in a change log or something as it's a change to a default. Though maybe I'm being too picky :)

And as this is hard-coded, yeah maybe we should look at making these configurable, but that's a discussion for the PTG :)
ok. at line 246 server is skipped if error limit > now, therefore server is available is error limit <= now.

Yeah, looks like all the filtering out of old stale times for self.errors happen in this function, but stale error_limitted isn't cleaned, just checked when calling.

I guess it's only ever 1 value per server so it's ok. and only used in a few places like Al mentioned. But starting to feel like we could add some helper methods to hide the complexity if we ever need to start adding more of these. Like self.is_error_limited(server) and self.get_avaible_servers() or self.get_error_limited_servers().

But that's really just NIT and something to add if we start doing more of this.

so as a consequence this server escapes being error-limited going forwards even once another server subsequently becomes available. How about an alternative strategy whereby this server is error-limited and the server closest to becoming un-error-limited is prematurely made available?

Once another server becomes available, the next error we get while talking to the server that skipped error-limiting will kick it over to being error-limited; it's not like we cleared self._errors[server] or anything.

Please do every param explicitely. This loop is making code less robust and harder to read.

I think this function has code duplication. Please see my comments above.
Please remove it. This has to be pure openstack API. tripleo package depends on opestack package, please don't make inverse dependency.

   keystone_credentials = keystone.get_keystone_credentials(

https://opendev.org/x/tobiko/src/branch/master/tobiko/openstack/keystone/_credentials.py#L31

I would then create test cases subclasses for testing the undercloud CLI passing the right ssh_client so we could cover both upstream CLI client and the one installed on the undercloud host, but explicitly.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I would prefer 'resurrect' to eliminate any doubt that the original is already dead at the point at which this is run.  'recreate' is a bit ambiguous in this respect - it could be misinterpreted to mean recreation of something which was shut down cleanly, or even cloning of something which is still running.

Thanks.  For the record, big bike-shedding discussion this morning on this:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-05-17.log.html#t2019-05-17T10:52:55

Discussion at the Train summit today [1] suggested we nest this as an option with the "openstack server migrate" command since (1) evacuate moves the server to another host (actually it rebuilds it on another host) and (2) server migrate is an admin-only command by default [people are used to that] and adding a top-level "openstack server recreate" command could confuse non-admin users into thinking they can perform the action by default.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/DEN-osc-compute-api-gaps
ill update this to resurrect and make the other changes and reuplod thanks

(4:10:17 PM) dansmith: I think keeping evacuate and relying on the scoping to disambiguate is the best plan at the moment
I'm leaving this as-is for now because there's clearly some disagreement here. Could be a good discussion for the mailing list or the next nova meeting
died

Just noting again there is some disagreement with this new naming since it could be confused as a new thing rather than just being the CLI for the evacuate API (not to be confused with the nova admin orchestration commands to live migrate all instances off a host). I would like to see some link to a discussion for agreement either in the ML or nova meeting before moving forward with this.

To correct myself, I realized it's not clear what Matt's opinion about the naming is -- he just noted that there's disagreement.

I just read through all the comments again and now see that there are users that wish to change the terminology for this command because they think it's clearer.

So ... I'll just echo what Matt has said, let's take the topic to the ML and see if there's wider consensus on which direction to go with the name. I thought using a new term would be confusing, but maybe most people would not find it so. I'd like to see a bit more input about it from more people before making the decision.

I just found this review because someone from our downstream docs team asked me, "Is there no openstack client command for "nova evacuate" or "nova host-evacuate"?" and opened the good ol etherpad:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/compute-api-microversion-gap-in-osc

I just want to note that I agree with Matt that we should not change the terminology in this command -- it makes it sound like a new thing IMHO. I'd prefer we stay consistent with the current name, even if it's not the best name.

Error should be checked before writing state

if error is received here, that means that inspection itself has failed, container maybe up and running at the same time. error indicated for example if you are using remote docker client, that you couldn't reach remote server because of network problems, and that doesn't mean that container is dead. it means, you fail to get the status.

OTOH, should this condition be independent of the nested else-ifs? I mean, should an an "if" statement be created after all the if-elsif conditions. It may happen that stopped nodes exist, but since they are in standby, alerts won't be thrown. However, other matches (eg. failed actions) could exist, but they wouldn't be evaluated (only the last elsif condition will have evaluated that the previous ones don't match).

My understanding is that $np->add_message can add as many messages as wanted, and the return code will be the worse (critical, if there are also messages in warning level). If this assumption is correct, all the elsif could be split into single "if" conditions.

Looking at [1] and [2] we need to make sure what's returned from cmdAdd and cmdDelete is types.Error to make sure it'll print it correctly using the correct CNI code we returned. Otherwise we'll get generic 100 error created at [2].

neutron/db/address_group_db.py.message: notify is deprecated, please add at least a TODO for it

I am perfectly aware that notify is deprecated. You should be aware, though, that the target for this notifications, the ML2 OVO RPC callback handler (https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/0431531b0c52a3d2693e749cd4c33329c285255a/neutron/plugins/ml2/ovo_rpc.py#L81-L82), receives old style notifications, which requires a context argument plus *args and **kwargs, as opposed to the new style used by publish, which receives an event payload (https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/callbacks/events.py#L53-L158). In this new style, the context is an attribute of the payload argument, which carries other state data that was previously conveyed by *args and **kwargs in the old style.

releasenotes/notes/scoping_REST_API-8665.message:
I'm not sure I follow the utility of this change. Either you are authorized on the current tenant or not. Why make this return a list if it is a binary answer?

Related, would it be more useful to keep the non scoped request to get a complete list?

I kept the list format for consistency between both endpoints, but a boolean would be indeed enough.

AuthZ and AuthN for the web UI are meant to be tenant-scoped, which limits the utility of the non scoped endpoint. And my understanding from previous discussions is that unscoped endpoints should be the exception, not the norm.

If we want to deprecate the non-scoped I think we don't have to keep that part consistent as it will be removed anyway in the future.

In this case I think we should consider getting just a bool (or maybe a data structure of the real permissions if we go towards more granular permissions at some time like read/admin or so).
